facts.text: Writ Petition No. 95 of 1964 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 95 of 1964. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petition seeks to quash order and notification dated October 3, 1963 issued by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: N. Subramonia Iyer, Arun B. Saharaya and Sardar Bhadur for the petitioner. P. Gopala Nambiar, Advocate-General for the State of Kerala and V. A. Seyid Muhammad, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao, J. This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution for issuing an appropriate writ to quash the order and numberification dated October 3, 1963, issued by the respondent

facts.text: Property Kizhakke Kottaram (Eastern Palace), 2 acres and 57 cents in survey Nos. 646 to 650 in Trivendrum City originally belonged to Maharaja of Travancore.

anchor.surface_text: Kizhakke Kottaram  i.e., Eastern Palace , 2 acres and 57 cents. in extent, companyprised in survey Nos. 646 to 650 and companysisting of land, trees, buildings, out-houses, the surrounding well on all sides, gates and all appurtenant, in the City of Trivendrum originally belonged to His Highness the Maharaja of Travancore,

facts.text: Maharaja sold the property to petitioner under sale deed dated January 7, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Under a sale deed dated January 7, 1959, the Maharaja sold the same to the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner has been in possession of the property including eastern wall since purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners case is that the eastern wall number in dispute is a portion of the Palace wall and is situate in survey Nos. 646 to 650 and that since the purchase he has been in possession of the same.

facts.text: Government of Kerala passed order G.O. MS No. 661/63/Edn dated October 3, 1963 under Travancore Ancient Monuments Preservation Regulation 1 of 1112/M.E.

anchor.surface_text: On October 3, 1963, the Government of Kerala passed an order, G.O.  MS  No. 661/63/Edn., purporting to be under the provisions of the Travancore Ancient Monuments Preservation Regulation 1 of 1112/M.E.  - 193637 A.D.

facts.text: Order considered Fort walls around Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple as of archaeological importance to be preserved as protected monument, including in survey Nos. 646-650.

anchor.surface_text: Under that order the Government companysidered the Fort walls around the Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple as of archaeological importance and that they should be preserved as a protected monument. Under that order the said are described as being situated, among others, in the aforesaid survey numbers also.

facts.text: State Government issued notification dated October 3, 1963 declaring the walls protected monument.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to that order the State Government issued a numberification dated October 3, 1963, declaring the said walls to be a protected monument for the purpose of the said Regulation

facts.text: Petitioner alleges part of walls in survey numbers belongs to him and infringes Art. 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, alleging that the part of the said walls situate in the said. survey numbers belonged to him and he was in possession thereof and that the said numberification infringed his fundamental right under Art. 19 1   f  of the Constitution, filed the present writ petition.

facts.text: State admits petitioner purchased Kizhakke Kottaram from Maharaja.

anchor.surface_text: The State filed a companynter-affidavit in which it admitted that the Kizhakke Kottaram was purchased by the petitioner from the Maharaja of Travancore,

facts.text: State contends eastern wall bounding Kizhakke Kottaram is part of fort wall, property of Travancore-Cochin and later Kerala Government.

anchor.surface_text: but companytended that the wan which bounded the Kizhakke Kottaram on the east was part of the fort wall which had always remained and companytinued to remain to be the property of the Travancore-Cochin, and later on Kerala, Government.

facts.text: State alleges petitioner deliberately intermeddled with the wall.

anchor.surface_text: It was further alleged that though the said wan was part of the historic fort wall, the petitioner deliberately intermeddled with it.

facts.text: Petitioner filed O.P. No. 1502 of 1960 in Kerala High Court for similar relief.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner filed O.P. No. 1502 of 1960 in the High Court of Kerala at Emakulam for a relief similar to that number sought in this petition.

facts.text: O.P. No. 1502/1960 dismissed by Vaidialingam J. on ground it sought declaration of title, foreign to Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: The said petition came up before Vaidialingam, J., who dismissed that petition on the ground that it sought for the declaration of title to the property in question, that the said relief was foreign to the scope of the proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Appeal against dismissal dismissed by Division Bench Raman Nair and Raghavan JJ.

anchor.surface_text: When an appeal was filed against that order a Division Bench of the High Court, companysisting of Raman Nair and Raghavan, JJ., dismissed the same, accepting the view of Vaidialingam, J., that the proper forum for the said relief was a civil Court.

facts.text: Kerala High Court did not go into merits but dismissed for alternative remedy.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the Kerala High Court did number go into the merits of the petitioners companytentions, but dismissed the petition for the reason that the petitioner had an effective remedy by way of a suit.

facts.text: Sale deed dated January 7, 1959 conveys Eastern Palace including outer compound walls, eastern boundary road.

anchor.surface_text: The Sale deed under which the petitioner has purchased the Eastern Palace from the Maharaja is filed along with the petition as Annexure A-2. Under the said sale deed, dated January 7, 1959, the Maharaja sold the Eastern Palace situate in survey Nos. 646 to 650,

facts.text: State admits execution of sale deed conveying palace to petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: In the companynter-affidavit the State, while admitting the title of the Maharaja to the Eastern Palace and the execution of the sale deed by him companyveying the said Palace to the petitioner,

facts.text: Petitioner in physical possession of disputed wall, admitted by State.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, withholding, our final decision on this point, as we are satisfied that the petitioner has purchased the disputed wall from the Maharaja and is in physical possession thereof. Indeed, the fact that he is in possession has been admitted by the State in its companynter-affidavit.

facts.text: Travancore Ancient Monuments Preservation Regulation 1 of 1112 M.E. (1936-37 A.D.) was valid State law.

anchor.surface_text: Regulation 1 of 1112 M.E. is of the year 1936 A.D. It was a State law and it is number disputed that it was validly made at the time it was passed.

facts.text: Regulation continued in force after formation of Travancore-Cochin State.

anchor.surface_text: After the Travancore-Cochin State was formed, under the Travancore-Cochin Administration and Application of Law Act, 1125 M.E.  Act VI of 1125 M.E.   1949 A.D , the existing laws of Travancore were extended to that part of the area of the new State which before the appointed day formed the territory of the State of Travancore.

facts.text: Ancient Monuments Preservation Act, 1904 extended to Travancore-Cochin by Part B States Laws Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Ile Part B States  Laws  Act, 1951  Act No. III of 1951  was made by Parliament and thereunder the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act, 1904, was extended to the new State of Travancore-Cochin.

facts.text: Court holds State Regulation continued to hold field as Central Act 1904 did not declare monuments of national importance.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the Central Act companyld number enter the field occupied by the State Legislature under List II. If so, it follows that the State Act held the field numberwithstanding the fact that the Central Act was extended to the State area.

facts.text: Notification issued under State Act was valid.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the numberification issued under the State Act was valid.

facts.text: Court withholds decision on whether disputed wall is part of historic Fort wall.

anchor.surface_text: It is number possible, without further evidence, on the basis of the affidavits filed by the petitioner and the State to companye to a definite companyclusion whether the disputed part of the wall is a part of the historic Fort wall. We are, therefore, withholding, our final decision on this point,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Kerala High Court did not go into merits of contentions but dismissed petition for effective alternative remedy by way of suit; no final decision negativing title.

holdings.text: The petitioner has possessory title in the wall and is, therefore entitled to be protected against interference with that right without the sanction of law.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has possessory title in the wall and is, therefore entitled to be protected against interference with that right without the sanction of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale deed prima facie conveys eastern wall; possession admitted by State in counter-affidavit.

holdings.text: For the aforesaid reasons it must be held that notwithstanding the extension of the Central Act VII of 1904 to the Travancore area and the passing of Central Acts LXXI of 1951 and XXIV of 1958, the State Act continued to hold the field in respect of the monument in question.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons it must be held that notwithstanding the extension of the Central Act VII of 1904 to the Travancore area and the passing of Central Acts LXXI of 1951 and XXIV of 1958, the State Act continued to hold the field in respect of the monument in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulation valid State law continued post-formation of Travancore-Cochin; Central Acts lack declaration of national importance per Entry 67 List I, cannot occupy State field under Entry 12 List II.

holdings.text: It follows that the notification issued under the State Act was valid.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the notification issued under the State Act was valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No implied repeal as Central Act 1904 extended subject to Parliament's legislative power; no national importance declaration prevents entry into State List field.

holdings.text: For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the Fort wall is a monument and the State Government was within its rights to issue the impugned notification under s. 3 of the State Regulation 1 of 1112 E.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the Fort wall is a monument and the State Government was within its rights to issue the impugned notification under s. 3 of the State Regulation 1 of 1112 E.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitution distinguishes monuments (State List) from sites/remains (Concurrent); dictionary meaning; State proceeded as monument; historical evidence as structure around temple, not site for exploration.

holdings.text: We are not deciding in this case whether the wall in dispute is part of the Fort wall.

anchor.surface_text: We are not deciding in this case whether the wall in dispute is part of the Fort wall.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insufficient evidence from affidavits; decision withheld; to be raised under Act provisions.

holdings.text: In this view, it is not necessary to express our opinion on the question whether Art. 363 of the Constitution is a bar to the maintainability of the petition.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as other grounds dispose of petition.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the Fort wall is a monument and the State Government was within its rights to issue the impugned notification under s. 3 of the State Regulation 1 of 1112 E. We are not deciding in this case whether the wall in dispute is part of the Fort wall. Such and other objections may be raised under the provisions of the Act in the manner prescribed thereunder. In this view, it is number necessary to express our opinion on the question whether Art. 363 of the Constitution is a bar to the maintainability of the petition.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, reject this contention.

For the aforesaid reasons we hold that the Fort wall is a monument and the State Government was within its rights to issue the impugned notification under s. 3 of the State Regulation 1 of 1112 E. We are not deciding in this case whether the wall in dispute is part of the Fort wall. Such and other objections may be raised under the provisions of the Act in the manner prescribed thereunder. In this view, it is number necessary to express our opinion on the question whether Art. 363 of the Constitution is a bar to the maintainability of the petition.
